review.title: Modelling Electricity Consumption in Office Buildings: An Agent Based Approach
review.abstract: In this paper, we develop an agent-based model which integrates four important elements, i.e. organisational energy management policies/regulations, energy management technologies, electric appliances and equipment, and human behaviour, to simulate the electricity consumption in office buildings. Based on a case study, we use this model to test the effectiveness of different electricity management strategies, and solve practical office electricity consumption problems. This paper theoretically contributes to an integration of the four elements involved in the complex organisational issue of office electricity consumption, and practically contributes to an application of an agent-based approach for office building electricity consumption study.

sections.text: In this paper, we develop an agent-based model that integrates four important elements: organizational energy management strategies / regulations, energy management technologies, electrical appliances and devices, and human behavior to simulate power consumption in office buildings. Building on a case study, we will use this model to test the effectiveness of different power management strategies and solve practical problems with power consumption in office buildings. This contribution theoretically contributes to the integration of the four elements involved in the complex organizational issue of office power consumption, and contributes practically to the application of an agent-based approach to power consumption in office building.Key wordsOffice power consumption, agent-based simulation, power management technologies, power management strategies

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Behaviour of Light Agents
sections.text: In the simulation model, we treat the lamps in the school building as passive agents, which means that these agents do not have a proactive behaviour, but react passively to the behaviour of the consumers of electricity. Behaviour of the lamps is relatively simple, as they can only be either switched off or switched on, as shown in the light scale (Figure 4). In the case of a light, the transition from the switched-off state to the switched-off state is linked to the presence of consumers of electricity when the light is automated by light sensors, or to the behaviour of switching on when there is a light switch that enables consumers of electricity to have control over the light. Conversely, the transition from the switched-on state to the switched-off state is linked to leaving the consumers of electricity when the light is automated by light sensors, or to the behaviour of switching off when there is a light switch.

sections.heading: 3.2.3 Behaviour of Computer Agents
sections.text: Similar to lamps, computers are treated as passive agents in our simulation model. Computers can be on, off, or in standby mode. Thus, in a computer's state plan, we look at these three states, as shown in Figure 5. For a computer, the transitions between off, on, and stand-by depend on the behavior of the power user agents when using the computer. According to our survey, the total power of a computer is 0 when the mode is off; 25 watts in standby mode; and about 400 watts when the mode is on.

sections.heading: 3.2.4 Model Implementation
sections.text: The model was implemented in the simulation package AnyLogic 6.5.0 [13] on a standard PC running Windows XP SP3. We set each time step in the simulation model to one minute and simulate the day-to-day work of the School of Computer Science staff and observe and analyze how their behavior can lead to systemic power consumption of the entire floor. Lighting and computer agents are assigned to each room based on their real physical distribution in the school. Electricity consumers come to school every morning, walk through the hallways and enter their own offices to work. They can also leave their offices, walk through the hallways and enter other rooms to use facilities such as toilets and kitchens. They interact with each other in relation to energy issues in the school, and this type of interaction can increase their energy conservation capacity. They also interact with passive light and computer agents, and this type of interaction can lead directly to systemic power consumption in the school. An overview of the model is shown in Figure 6.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text: This paper describes an agent-based model of the energy consumption of office buildings. We started the work with an argument for integrating the four elements involved in the energy consumption of office buildings, and then described the agent-based simulation method and the reasons for developing an agent-based model for investigating the power consumption of office buildings. We then developed an agent-based model of the energy consumption of office buildings using the example of the School of Computer Science, Jubilee Campus, University of Nottingham, and presented the simulation results. We focused on two objectives: First, integrating the four elements involved in the energy consumption of office buildings into one model. The other is the development of a multi-layer framework for investigating practical issues of energy management for an organization. From the research results we reported in this paper, we conclude that while it is not possible to perfectly replicate the real organization, the agent-based simulation as a novel approach that integrates the four elements of the energy consumption of office buildings is a very useful tool for the office building.
